Special Wallbreaker.description: Hoopa is a passable wallbreaker that fits on offensive teams, particularly when paired with Sticky Web support from Masquerain and Spidops and teammates that can pivot it in safely. Psyshock allows Hoopa to hit special walls like Blissey on their weaker physical bulk, while Knock Off cripples RegenVest users like Alolan Muk and Meloetta that can otherwise take a hit and threaten a KO or pivot out to a faster offensive threat like Chien-Pao. Focus Blast 2HKOes Hisuian Goodra and KOes Kingambit that would attempt to switch in. Defensive pivots that can take a hit and pivot out like Corviknight and Meloetta can get Hoopa in safely. Dual screens setters like Prankster Corviknight and Mew also make for a good partner, as they allow Hoopa to have an easier time setting up with Nasty Plot or tank a hit in a pinch and retaliate. Offensive pivots like Slither Wing and Galarian Zapdos pair well with Hoopa with their ability to bait in and pivot out on checks like Corviknight and defensive Zapdos, allowing Hoopa to set up and threaten a KO; faster offensive threats like Chien-Pao and Barraskewda also pair well with it by making up for its lackluster Speed while Hoopa threatens out their checks like defensive Quaquaval.

Primordial Sea.description: Primordial Sea Volcanion excels as a fantastic wallbreaker with its great Special Attack and offensive typing. Rain-boosted Steam Eruption combined with Choice Specs allows Volcanion to 2HKO most Pokemon in tier, including most specially defensive walls such as RegenVest Garchomp, Meloetta, and Alolan Muk. Weather Ball dissuades promient Desolate Land users that might want to switch in to Volcanion such as Cinderace and Iron Moth. Earth Power is a more reliable way to deal with Desolate Land users like Iron Moth and Heatran, and it's a reliable way to hit Hisuian Goodra without missing. Focus Blast 2HKOes a would-be check in RegenVest Roaring Moon, as well as Hisuian Goodra after Spikes chip. Volcanion pairs well with entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Garchomp, which help wear down common RegenVest Pokemon like Goodra and Hisuian Goodra, and hazards also guarantee a 2HKO on Meloetta. Due to Volcanion's Stealth Rock weakness it pairs well with hazard removers like Corviknight and Quaquaval, which can also help pivot it in safely. Volcanion also pairs well with offensive pivots like Zapdos and Roaring Moon, which can help bring it in on targets like Corviknight.

Magic Guard.description: Magic Guard Volcanion serves as a great mixed wallbreaker with a typing that also offers defensive utility. Flare Blitz is notably able to 2HKO RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta, and Steam Eruption's burn chance deters would-be switch-ins like defensive Quaquaval and Garchomp. Earth Power reliably threatens Toxapex and Desolate Land users such as Iron Moth, Skeledirge, and Cinderace. Taunt can be used to hinder defensive walls with recovery such as Scream Tail and Quaquaval, while Will-O-Wisp is able to reliably burn switch-ins like defensive Quaquaval and Garchomp. Flame Charge is also a niche option to outspeed common revenge killers to Volcanion like Zapdos, Hisuian Arcanine, and Choice Band Galarian Zapdos. Magic Guard helps Volcanion with its weakness to entry hazards while also negating recoil from Flare Blitz and Life Orb. Offensive pivots such as Slither Wing and Iron Moth can bring Volcanion in against defensive cores featuring staples like Intimidate Corviknight and RegenVest users. Fast late-game cleaners like Chien-Pao and Regieleki also appreciate Volcanion's ability to weaken defensive checks like Quaquaval and common RegenVest users, which can allow them to take over games, while also providing speed control against faster threats to Volcanion like Zapdos, Hisuian Electrode, and Roaring Moon. Volcanion's susceptibility to being revenge killed by aformetioned threats makes defensive partners such as Corviknight and Meloetta essential, as they can tank hits and also help pivot to bring in Volcanion safely. Despite being immune to hazards, Volcanion still lacks recovery, so a teammate that can grant it longevity like Wish Scream Tail is also appreciated.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Primarina is an excellent wallbreaker thanks to its great typing and strong, nearly unresisted STAB combination. Weather Ball lets Primarina 2HKO RegenVest Swampert while still being able to hit Desolate Land users such as Heatran. Flip Turn allows Primarina to pivot away from problematic matchups like Empoleon and Blissey as well as predicted switch-ins in order to maintain momentum, while Psychic lets it hit Poison-types such as Toxapex and Desolate Land Iron Moth. Primarina is relatively slow and struggles to switch in, so it appreciates other slow pivots such as Corviknight and Swampert; in return, it can threaten wallbreakers that come in on them such as Cinderace and Roaring Moon. Corviknight especially is a great partner, as it can also remove entry hazards, which wear down Primarina very quickly due to its lack of recovery and frequent pivoting. Primarina struggles against special walls such as Manaphy, Meloetta, and Bulletproof Empoleon, so physical wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Iron Hands make for great teammates; in return, Primarina can apply pressure on physical walls such as Corviknight and Great Tusk for them, wearing down each other's checks.

RegenVest.description: With its great typing and natural bulk, Primarina can pivot into and check several of the tier's prominent threats including Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Walking Wake. Psychic Noise threatens Iron Moth and denies recovery to it and Heatran, which could otherwise block Flip Turn with Desolate Land. Energy Ball hits Water-types like Swampert and opposing Primarina, while Surf provides a spammable Water-type move that also hits Steel-types like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Physical walls like Deoxys-D and Pecharunt appreciate Primarina's ability to switch into Dark-types that threaten them out like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao; in return, they can check threats like Iron Hands and Ogerpon-H that threaten Primarina. Frail offensive teammates like Deoxys-S, Azelf, and Chien-Pao appreciate Primarina's ability to switch into powerful attackers and safely pivot them in. Electric-types like Zapdos and Hisuian Electrode can easily break past Primarina, making Pokemon that can handle them like Roaring Moon and Volt Absorb Corviknight great teammates. Desolate Land users like Ceruledge, Heatran, and Iron Moth prevent Primarina from pivoting with Flip Turn and can threaten significant damage against it, making teammates that can deal with them like Primordial Sea Barraskewda and Zapdos appreciated. Primarina is also prone to getting worn down by entry hazards, so hazard removers like Corviknight and the aforementioned Great Tusk are good partners; it also forms a great defensive core with them, as it can help check Pokemon that pressure them like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon, giving them more opportunities to remove hazards.

Physically Defensive.description: Toxapex is a stout physically defensive wall that deters common physical attackers like Galarian Zapdos and Ceruledge. Toxic targets foes that commonly run Heavy-Duty Boots or are Ground immune like Cinderace and Galarian Zapdos, while Toxic Spikes provides excellent team support; Corrosion variants should always run Toxic to punish common switch-ins like Corviknight and Hisuian Goodra that otherwise might use Toxapex as free recovery. Prankster + Haze, on the other hand, is an excellent tool to frustrate hyper offense teams and stop dangerous setup sweepers like Chien-Pao, Polteageist, and Chesnaught. While the consistent recovery of Black Sludge is generally preferred, Rocky Helmet allows Toxapex to annoy non-Magic Guard Galarian Zapdos and Chien-Pao even when it is forced to use Recover. Toxapex is utterly unable to threaten most Magic Guard users, like Galarian Zapdos and especially Water-resistant ones like Hisuian Electrode and Quaquaval, so reliable checks to them like Hisuian Goodra and Fluffy Corviknight are recommended. Toxic Spikes variants appreciate spinners like Iron Treads, as they can provide entry hazard removal without removing Toxic Spikes as well. Toxapex can easily be overwhelmed by multiple attackers, so it should always have a secondary physically defensive teammate, especially one that handles Ground-types, like Intimidate Corviknight; this also relieves some of the pressure off of Toxapex of checking pivots without Regenerator.

Court Change.description: With Cinderace's high Speed, high-Base Power STAB move in Pyro Ball, and general utility, it makes for a decent offensive pivot. U-turn lets Cinderace pivot on checks like Manaphy, Primarina, Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, and Skarmory while also safely getting teammates in that can take these checks on such as Sandy Shocks, Iron Hands, and Galarian Zapdos. Court Change lets Cinderace support its teammates by potentially clearing its side of entry hazards and using them against the opponent while also being able to steal dual screens. Will-O-Wisp lets Cinderace cripple potential switch-ins such as Dragonite, Garchomp, and Great Tusk, but it can instead use Taunt to cripple defensive Pokemon like Deoxys-D, Scream Tail, and Pecharunt. With High Jump Kick Cinderace can cover Primordial Sea switch-ins such as Barraskewda and Walking Wake. Frail offensive Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Barraskewda, and Azelf appreciate the presence of Cinderace due to it not only allowing them easier entry onto the field but also removing checks to them such as Corviknight, Scream Tail, and Mandibuzz. Cinderace falters when having to deal with either Primordial Sea users like Zapdos and Primarina or Well-Baked Body users such as Gholdengo and Corviknight, so having teammates such as Swampert, Empoleon, and RegenVest Roaring Moon to check these Pokemon is immensely helpful. As a final note, Cinderace tends to be used on more offensive teams, but with Court Change not fully removing hazards, it's not recommended that you use multiple hazard-weak teammates with it.

Choice Band.description: Cinderace leverages its high Attack and Speed stats alongside its high-Base Power moves to be a great offensive pivot and wallbreaker, threatening common physical walls like Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Deoxys-D. High Jump Kick is Cinderace's best move against Well-Baked Body Steel-types, doing sizable damage to Corviknight and Skarmory and OHKOing Kingambit. U-turn lets Cinderace pivot out of problematic matchups like Ceruledge and Well-Baked Body Gholdengo while also threatening Latios, whereas Gunk Shot threatens Primarina and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Desolate Land gives Cinderace a very high chance of OHKOing offensive Great Tusk after Spikes damage and lets it come in and threaten out Primordial Sea users like Zapdos and, when they're locked into Water-type moves, Barraskewda and Walking Wake. Alternatively, Sword of Ruin lets High Jump Kick OHKO Walking Wake and 2HKO Well-Baked Body Corviknight after slight chip damage. Fast physical attackers like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao appreciate Cinderace threatening their checks like non-Well-Baked Body Corviknight and RegenVest Primarina, letting them sweep once these foes have been removed. In return, they can pressure Well-Baked Body Steel-types that trouble Cinderace like Gholdengo and Corviknight. While fast, Cinderace is also frail and prone to getting revenge killed by faster foes like Iron Boulder and Choice Scarf Azelf, so teammates that can deal with them like Fluffy Corviknight and Empoleon are appreciated. Additionally, Cinderace is prone to getting worn down by entry hazards, making hazard removers like Great Tusk and the aforementioned Corviknight great partners.

Swords Dance.description: Cinderace's high Attack and Speed combined with great coverage options and Swords Dance turn it into a powerful wallbreaker and cleaner. High Jump Kick threatens Roaring Moon and OHKOes Well-Baked Body Kingambit, while Gunk Shot threatens to cripple switch-ins such as Manaphy, Zapdos, Kommo-o, and physically defensive Garchomp. Life Orb lets High Jump Kick OHKO RegenVest Roaring Moon and lets Gunk Shot 2HKO Primordial Sea Zapdos, while Heavy-Duty Boots increases Cinderace's longevity. Desolate Land lets Cinderace come in on and force out Primordial Sea users like Zapdos if safely pivoted in by a teammate while also letting +2 Life Orb-boosted Pyro Ball OHKO defensive Great Tusk. Sword of Ruin + Heavy-Duty Boots provides more damage on Cinderace's coverage moves at the cost of a worse matchup into Primordial Sea and lowered damage on Pyro Ball. Fast cleaners such as Barraskewda and Dragonite appreciate Cinderace's ability to pressure their walls like Corviknight and Scream Tail, opening up the way for them to sweep late-game. Special pivots like Azelf, Zapdos, and Walking Wake are appreciated, as they can pivot Cinderace in against their switch-ins, such as Empoleon and Hisuian Goodra. Cinderace's frailty means it's easily revenge killed by most Pokemon faster than it like Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf Azelf, so teammates that can take a hit for it and pivot it in such as Corviknight and Manaphy are appreciated. Cinderace is also completely walled by Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, so teammates that can threaten it like Garchomp and Roaring Moon are appreciated.

Utility.description: Cinderace is a good utility pivot thanks to its high Speed and great supporting movepool. U-turn lets it pivot out against Well-Baked Body Pokemon like Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Kingambit, as well as Primordial Sea users like Zapdos, Walking Wake, and Manaphy. Court Change punishes opposing teams for setting entry hazards or dual screens. Super Fang can be used instead to chip switch-ins like Kommo-o, Garganacl, and Quaquaval that Cinderace cannot meaningfully damage otherwise. Taunt prevents status moves, entry hazards, and recovery, which can help against foes like Scream Tail, while Will-O-Wisp cripples checks like Garchomp, Kommo-o, and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Cinderace is threatened by Primordial Sea users like Barraskewda, Ogerpon-W, and Walking Wake, which force it out, making walls like defensive Zapdos, Kommo-o, and Empoleon pair well with it. Offensive pivots such as Galarian Zapdos, Meowscarada, and Sandy Shocks pair well with Cinderace, as they form a VoltTurn core with it, being able to pivot it in to threaten walls like Corviknight, Meloetta, Hisuian Goodra. In return, Cinderace can pivot these teammates in to threaten its switch-ins like Kommo-o, Garaganacl, and Quaquaval.

Primordial Sea.description: Inteleon is a strong wallbreaker that fits well on balance and bulky offense teams. U-turn allows it to pivot out on switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra and Blissey while also forming strong VoltTurn cores with other pivots like Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing that can wear down each other's checks with entry hazards up. Mud Shot allows it to threaten Desolate Land Fire-types like Iron Moth and Cinderace that would otherwise switch into Inteleon freely. Ice Beam allows it to chip specially bulky Dragon-types like RegenVest Roaring Moon and Goodra, while Surf acts as a more reliable option late-game when the opposing team has been heavily chipped or to snipe frailer or slower targets like Azelf and both Zapdos formes. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon appreciate Inteleon pivoting into them on its switch-ins like the aforementioned Hisuian Goodra and Blissey as well as Inteleon's ability to threaten physical walls like Corviknight and defensive Quaquaval. Inteleon brings close to no defensive utility bar a Fire-type move immunity, which means that walls like Corviknight and Goodra are a must-have to make up for the lack of defensive utility; these Pokemon also switch into revenge killing attempts from Slither Wing and Regieleki. Inteleon appreciates Spikes support from Pokemon like Garchomp and Ting-Lu that helps it to wear down RegenVest Pokemon like Meloetta and Alolan Muk.

Physically Defensive.description: Corviknight's unparalleled role compression as a physical wall, entry hazard remover, and slow pivot that doesn't need Regenerator makes it a defensive staple on the majority of teams. Fluffy provides the most protection against wallbreakers like Choice Band Galarian Zapdos, Iron Boulder, and Roaring Moon while not letting Corviknight fall victim to Scrappy Great Tusk, whereas Intimidate provides additional protection against Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-C at the cost of needing a secondary physical check to deal with the aforementioned threats reliably. Brave Bird is Corviknight's strongest neutral move and hits Ghost-types and key targets like Great Tusk and Galarian Zapdos, while Body Press fits well on Intimidate sets to do more damage to Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-C, and Chien-Pao. Corviknight is exceedingly passive, so it needs powerful and fast offensive teammates like Barraskewda and Azelf to re-gain momentum; in exchange, it provides them safe entry with its slow U-turn and entry hazard removal. Slower wallbreakers like Galarian Zapdos and Ceruledge also appreciate Corviknight's slow pivoting services. Corviknight, especially Fluffy variants, needs a teammate like Swampert, Manaphy, or Well-Baked Body Gholdengo to handle the Fire-types it cannot check. Hazard-weak teammates like Chien-Pao and the Ogerpon formes appreciate Corviknight's ability to remove hazards semi-reliably.

Dual Screens.description: Prankster and an excellent defensive typing enable Corviknight to set dual screens multiple times a battle for hyper offense teams. Taunt lets Corviknight prevent opposing Corviknight from removing dual screens with Defog, stop Pokemon like Deoxys-D and Great Tusk from setting entry hazards, and prevent Pokemon like Dragonite and Gholdengo from setting up. U-turn is used to pivot out once dual screens have been set up. Prankster Corviknight should be used with setup sweepers that appreciate dual screens support such as Dragonite, Volcarona, and Iron Boulder. Fire-types like Iron Moth, Ceruledge, and Heatran and Electric-types like Zapdos can deal heavy damage to Corviknight, so having Dragon-types that can check them like Roaring Moon and Dragonite is appreciated.

Choice Band.description: With great offensive stats and a spammable move in Flip Turn, Barraskewda serves as an excellent offensive pivot that's capable of outpacing the majority of the metagame. Close Combat lets it deal with foes that resist its Water-type moves such as Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-W, and Walking Wake, while Aqua Jet lets it pick off weakened foes that normally outspeed it such as Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks and Hisuian Electrode, as well as foes that have set up, such as Volcarona and Great Tusk. Drill Run and Psychic Fangs also threaten Water-resistant foes, with Drill Run OHKOing Desolate Land Fire-types such as Iron Moth, Heatran, and Ceruledge and Psychic Fangs threatening Quaquaval and Kommo-o. Barraskewda takes great advantage of weakened walls such as Corviknight and Deoxys-D, making physical wallbreakers such as Iron Boulder, Galarian Zapdos, and Ceruledge good partners. Specially offensive pivots such as Hisuian Electrode and Azelf form great VoltTurn cores with Barraskewda, since they're able to threaten each other's checks, with Barraskewda forcing out special walls such as Meloetta and Swampert while they threaten physical walls such as Corviknight and Quaquaval in return. Barraskewda is very frail and easily OHKOed by faster foes such as Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Azelf, which makes defensive pivots such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Swampert necessary. It also struggles a lot with entry hazards, making hazard removers such as Great Tusk and Corviknight appreciated.

Shell Smash.description: Polteageist is a dangerous setup sweeper and cleaner thanks to Shell Smash, Stored Power, and its excellent Special Attack, allowing it to sweep with a single turn of setup. Giga Drain provides coverage for Ting-Lu and Garganacl, Strength Sap gives Polteageist a way to restore its Focus Sash after chip damage and set up on weaker physical attackers, while Substitute allows for safe setup on status-reliant walls like Blissey. Focus Sash the preferred item to safely ensure Polteageist can use Shell Smash. Polteageist can often struggle to get itself onto the field safely, so it appreciates a slow pivot from Corviknight or Shed Tail Cyclizar who can also facilitate Polteageist's setup with screens or a passed Substitute. Polteageist pairs well with physical wallbreakers like Swords Dance Cinderace that can break through opposing walls. Due to its reliance on Focus Sash, Polteageist needs reliable entry hazard removal like Cyclizar and Iron Treads.

Choice Band.description: With Zamazenta's high Attack only compounded by Sword of Ruin and excellent Speed tier that allows it to outspeed nearly the entire unboosted metagame, it serves as a potent wallbreaker that is capable of 2HKOing even dedicated physical walls like Mandibuzz and defensive Great Tusk with Close Combat. Crunch 2HKOes Psychic- and Ghost-types like Deoxys-D, Pecharunt, and physically defensive Gholdengo variants that would switch into Close Combat. Stone Edge helps against Flying-types like Zapdos and Dragonite that might otherwise survive a hit and KO Zamazenta back. Heavy Slam covers Fairy-type switch-ins like Scream Tail and Primarina. Due to Zamazenta's lack of reliable recovery, it appreciates entry hazard removal support from Great Tusk and Corviknight, the latter of which can also serve as a slow pivot to bring it in safely and help preserve its HP so it can take advantage of its great natural bulk. Zamazenta benefits from Knock Off users like Roaring Moon and Iron Treads removing Rocky Helmets, keeping it from getting worn down. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Deoxys-D help to chip down the likes of Fluffy Corviknight and Great Tusk to make them easier for Zamazenta to KO. Zamazenta is susceptible to being revenge killed by Choice Scarf Azelf, Dragonite, and most Deoxys-S variants, so defensive walls like Deoxys-D, Hisuian Goodra, and Scream Tail that can switch into them are needed.

IronPress.description: Zamazenta-C leverages its high bulk and Speed to be an excellent setup sweeper with Iron Defense + Body Press while also being able to check many of the tier's dangerous offensive threats with its excellent defensive typing. Zamazenta-C can only use Dauntless Shield, which increases its potency as a setup sweeper while boosting Body Press. Stone Edge threatens an OHKO on Iron Moth while 2HKOing Dragonite, Ceruledge, and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Substitute can be used to block status and phazing moves, notably surviving a Scald from defensive Manaphy and a Dragon Tail from Garchomp, as well as pivoting moves from defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight, Empoleon, Mandibuzz, and Manaphy. Special wallbreakers such as Gengar, Azelf, and Walking Wake appreciate Zamazenta-C being able to threaten switch-ins to them such as Empoleon, Hisuian Goodra, and RegenVest Roaring Moon, as well as offensive checks such as Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Ogerpon-C, as the aforementioned teammates are otherwise forced out by the threat of an OHKO; in return, they can remove Zamazenta-C's checks, such as defensive Kommo-o and Zapdos. Zamazenta-C struggles with physically defensive Pokemon that can counter it by setting up on their own, such as Iron Defense Kommo-o and Corviknight, as well as Bulk Up Great Tusk, so teammates that can check them such as Zapdos and Scream Tail are appreciated, with the latter being able to pass Wishes to Zamazenta-C. Zamazenta-C is also weak to entry hazards, so teammates that can remove hazards such as Corviknight and Great Tusk are appreciated.

Refrigerate.description: An amazing Speed stat combined with Refrigerate earns Regieleki a niche as a spinner that cannot be spinblocked and a pivot that can threaten common Pokemon that block Volt Switch such as Garchomp and Great Tusk. Extreme Speed OHKOes Dragonite and offensive Garchomp and 2HKOes Roaring Moon and offensive Zapdos. Tera Blast 2HKOes defensive Great Tusk and chips defensive Kommo-o and Zapdos, while Thunderbolt can be used to better pressure Corviknight and Ice-resistant foes such as Manaphy, Iron Moth, and Heatran attempting to switch in. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Regieleki ignore the entry hazards it removes, while Never-Melt Ice lets Extreme Speed OHKO Hisuian Electrode and specially defensive Garchomp and lets Tera Blast 2HKO defensive Zapdos. Wallbreakers such as Ceruledge and Ogerpon-H appreciate Regieleki being able to safely pivot them in on Pokemon they threaten such as Iron Moth and Heatran while also removing the entry hazards they're weak to; in return, they can threaten the bulky Pokemon that Regieleki struggles to break through such as Scream Tail, Hisuian Goodra, and Volt Absorb Empoleon. Additionally, Regieleki's ability to outspeed and threaten Choice Scarf Azelf is valuable, as Azelf can OHKO the aforementioned wallbreakers after Stealth Rock chip. Regieleki's poor bulk makes it an unreliable entry hazard remover on its own; therefore it's recommended to pair it with another hazard remover such as Great Tusk, Corviknight, or Mandibuzz, with the latter two forming a VoltTurn core with the momentum they generate from their pivoting moves. Physical pivots such as Barraskewda, Roaring Moon, and Meowscarada are also recommended teammates, as they also create a VoltTurn core, while Regieleki lures in special walls such as Heatran, Meloetta, and Manaphy that they can force out.

Choice Item.description: Thanks to its high base Attack and Speed stats and U-turn, Meowscarada functions incredibly as an offensive pivot and wallbreaker. U-turn allows Meowscarada to switch out of problematic matchups such as Corviknight and Kingambit and into threats like Iron Moth and Iron Hands to scare them away. Trick enables Meowscarada to punish bulky walls like Corviknight, Skarmory, and Mandibuzz looking to switch in on it; alternatively, Triple Axel provides a way for Meowscarada to hit Dragonite, Mandibuzz, and Chesnaught for super effective damage. Meowscarada can use Choice Band to OHKO Deoxys-D, Walking Wake, and Garganacl after Stealth Rock, while Choice Scarf gives it the ability to outspeed incredibly fast foes such as Deoxys-S, Choice Scarf Azelf, and Roaring Moon. Since Meowscarada struggles against Corviknight, Skarmory, and Kingambit, it appreciates partners like Zapdos, Sandy Shocks, and Archaludon that can pressure them; in return, Meowscarada can threaten Swampert and Meloetta, which these teammates struggle against. While Meowscarada's Attack stat is adequate, it still appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Deoxys-D, Garchomp, and Heatran, as Stealth Rock or one layer of Spikes allows Meowscarada to have a very high chance of OHKOing Deoxys-D and Scream Tail.

Spinblocker.description: Thanks to its typing and good physical bulk, Skeledirge serves as an excellent spinblocker that can wall common spinners such as Iron Treads with Earth Eater and Quaquaval with Desolate Land. It also walls threats like Choice Band Cinderace and Zamazenta-C and, depending on its ability, Garchomp and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Skeledirge can then use Torch Song to set up on passive opponents like Scream Tail and non-Well-Baked Body Blissey or Will-O-Wisp to burn an incoming foe, including switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra and Alolan Muk. Hex alongside Will-O-Wisp does more damage, but Shadow Ball can be used for more consistent damage. Skeledirge pairs well with hazard setters such as Garchomp and Iron Treads, as it allows them to keep their hazards on the field, and they can in turn handle opposing Well-Baked Body Pokemon. Due to its middling Special Defense, Skeledirge appreciates specially defensive teammates like Blissey and Hisuian Goodra. Additionally, a teammate that covers the type that Skeledirge chooses not to be immune to, such as Quaquaval for Earth Eater variants and Corviknight for Desolate Land variants, helps form a strong defensive core. Dark-types like Meowscarada and Chien-Pao also OHKO Skeledirge with a bit of chip damage, so Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing that can threaten them are appreciated.

Physically Defensive.description: Due to its incredible utility moves in Rapid Spin and Knock Off, longevity from Roost, and good typing, Quaquaval functions incredibly as an entry hazard remover and pivot and checks Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Barraskewda. Quaquaval has a multitude of viable abilities, such as Scrappy to let Rapid Spin and Low Kick affect Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Ceruledge as well as Intimidate and Fluffy to further increase its bulk, allowing it to more safely switch in on top physical threats such as Roaring Moon and offensive Great Tusk. Thanks to U-turn, Quaquaval can allow frail attackers including Azelf and Meowscarada to safely switch in. Knock Off can be used for its general reliability and utility, while Low Kick wears down opposing Hisuian Goodra and Blissey. Quaquaval is quite vulnerable to special attackers such as Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Hisuian Electrode. To counter these significant threats, RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta can be used to safely switch in on most of their attacks and threaten to deal decent chip damage to them with Knock Off or U-turn. Some teammates that benefit from Quaquaval's presence include Roaring Moon and Deoxys-S, as they don't enjoy taking Spikes damage, so they appreciate its hazard removing capabilities.

Magic Guard.description: Quaquaval is a decent wallbreaker, using its strong STAB moves, and solid Attack stat to burst through bulky opponents foes like Great Tusk, Deoxys-D, and Skarmory. Brave Bird hits Desolate Land users such as Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Ceruledge on the switch-in, but Quaquaval can use Close Combat to help against Pokemon like Heatran and Manaphy, though this does have the drawback of making it easier to be revenge killed. Rapid Spin is used as not only entry hazard removal for Quaquaval and its teammates but also a way to let it outspeed and threaten foes like Hisuian Electrode, Galarian Zapdos, and Iron Boulder. Knock Off can be used to both remove items from Pokemon like Corviknight, Deoxys-D, and Mandibuzz, as well as hit Ghost-types such as Ceruledge and Gholdengo. U-turn is a less prominent option to be able to pivot on checks like Corviknight and Manaphy. Roost is used to keep Quaquaval healthy potentially allowing it to outlast its checks, while Swords Dance can be used as a way to let it end games by blasting through its checks like Corviknight, Gholdengo, and physically defensive Manaphy. Offensive Psychic-types such as Azelf, Iron Boulder, and Deoxys-S appreciate Quaquaval's presence, as it's able to take on Dark- and Steel-types such as Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, and Gholdengo for them. Quaquaval is slow, and struggles to deal with faster foes such as Deoxys-S, Dragonite, and Latios, so it benefits from having teammates like Swampert, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz to help with checking them defensively and bringing it in safely.

Specially Defensive.description: Garganacl finds itself as a Stealth Rock setter that fits on balance and stall teams with its ability to force progress through passive damage and maintain entry hazards by annoying popular hazard removal options with Salt Cure. Earth Eater allows it to check and set up with Iron Defense or Curse on Ground-types like Iron Treads, Landorus-T, and Garchomp, and Water Absorb allows it to check Greninja, Inteleon, and Quaquaval lacking Close Combat. Stealth Rock pairs well with Salt Cure, as Salt Cure heavily chips common hazard removal options like Iron Treads and Corviknight, while Iron Defense and Curse allow Garganacl to act as a bulky cleaner late-game. Protect allows Garganacl to scout the opponent's move, heal with Leftovers, and force more passive damage on foes, while Earthquake and Body Press hit Magic Guard Pokemon like Quaquaval and Heatran that otherwise switch in freely. Garganacl's inability to check common special wallbreakers like Sheer Force Iron Moth and Enamorus-T makes pivots like Regieleki and Slither Wing and physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao great partners; in return, they appreciate Garganacl's ability to maintain Stealth Rock on the field and annoy their checks like Hisuian Goodra and Corviknight with Salt Cure. Garganacl gets rapidly worn down by entry hazards when carrying Leftovers, making physically defensive hazard removal options like Corviknight and defensive Quaquaval good partners; these Pokemon also check physical wallbreakers that threaten Garganacl like Galarian Zapdos, while it checks the special wallbreakers that threaten them. The aforementioned Magic Guard Quaquaval checks Garganacl lacking Iron Defense + Body Press and can spin away Garganacl's Stealth Rock; Desolate Land Skeledirge can spinblock Quaquaval effectively, making it a good partner for Garganacl.

Choice Band.description: Ceruledge has the perfect combination of traits to become a terrifying wallbreaker, boasting two of the best offensive STAB typings, high-Base Power attacks, and a naturally good matchup against the tier's most common physical wall, Corviknight. Bitter Blade's healing is greatly appreciated to offset Stealth Rock chip damage, and Close Combat flips the table on potential answers such as Roaring Moon and Well-Baked Body Kingambit. Shadow Sneak makes Ceruledge a potent revenge killer and cleaner, picking off weakened setup sweepers like Volcarona and Ogerpon-C, and threatening to OHKO Iron Boulder, Gengar, and non-Psychic Surge Deoxys-S. An Adamant nature helps Ceruledge secure certain KOs, most notably OHKOing Swampert with Poltergeist, but Jolly allows it to outspeed Gholdengo and neutral-natured Great Tusk. Ceruledge requires slow pivots like Primarina, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz to get it onto the field, with the former covering Walking Wake and the latter two providing valuable Defog support while also checking dangerous revenge killers like Roaring Moon and Dragonite. Ceruledge also pairs well with offensive pivots like Walking Wake and Zapdos, both of which require help to break past RegenVest users such as Manaphy and Swampert; in return, they give it more opportunities to come in to wallbreak. However, Ceruledge cannot be paired with Knock Off as this nullifies Poltergeist, limiting its synergy with the aforementioned RegenVests users and common Choice Scarf users like Roaring Moon and Meowscarada. Ceruledge is quite slow relative to other offensive wallbreakers, so it needs speed control in the form of Chien-Pao and Barraskewda, the latter of which also baits in and pivots on Corviknight and Skarmory.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Ceruledge is one of the tier's most potent wallbreakers and setup sweepers thanks to its high base Attack, great STAB coverage, and Swords Dance. Shadow Sneak picks off weakened foes like Gholdengo and Iron Boulder and OHKOes frailer targets like Sheer Force Deoxys-S, while Close Combat nails potential Dark-type switch-ins like Roaring Moon. Sword of Ruin offers the most all-around damage amplification, while Desolate Land supercharges Bitter Blade and provides a useful immunity to Water; similarly, Life Orb provides extra power, letting Ceruledge achieve feats like OHKOing Deoxys-D, while Heavy-Duty Boots is useful on teams with weak entry hazard removal. Ceruledge can be overwhelmed by Pokemon like Barraskewda, Ogerpon-W, and Psychic Surge Deoxys-S, making defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and Deoxys-D good teammates. Ceruledge's low Speed means that it can easily be outsped by foes, making offensive Pokemon like Choice Scarf Azelf, Dragonite, and Chien-Pao good teammates that help make up for it thanks to their high Speed. Ceruledge's poor defenses and weakness to entry hazards makes slow, hazard-removing pivots like Corviknight and Mandibuzz ideal teammates. Because Ceruledge relies heavily on Poltergeist, it has poor synergy teammates that frequently use Knock Off such as Manaphy and Swampert.

Tinted Lens.description: Tinted Lens Tinkaton is a solid physical wallbreaker that provides utility while using Tinted Lens to bypass resistances to Gigaton Hammer, turning the tables on defensive Quaquaval and Corviknight, activating teammates like Choice Band Chien-Pao that are hindered by these Pokemon. Metal Coat can be considered as it grants Tinkaton a boosting option for Gigaton Hammer without recoil, granting good odds of OHKOing frailer offensive Pokemon like Ceruledge and Magic Guard Quaquaval after minor chip. Swords Dance allows Tinkaton to more effectively wallbreak, Knock Off is excellent utility that cripples switch-ins like Magic Guard Heatran and Volcanion while annoying switch-ins like Corviknight and Iron Treads, Stealth Rock allows it to act as an offensive entry hazard setter, Protect allows it to gain more Leftovers recovery on Gigaton Hammer's cooldown turn, and Thunder Wave cripples setup sweepers that may try to capitalize on Gigaton Hammer's cooldown turn. Tinkaton appreciates slow pivots like Corviknight and Meloetta that can live a hit and pivot in Tinkaton safely. Tinkaton also appreciates faster teammates that make up for its lackluster Speed like Roaring Moon and Hisuian Electrode. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu pair well with Tinkaton, as it forces numerous switches and removes Heavy-Duty Boots.

Palafin.description: Palafin's powerful priority offense and pivoting make it a dangerous threat even with its standard ability. Jet Punch from Palafin-H easily revenge kills dangerous threats like Kilowattrel, Sandy Shocks, and Talonflame, as well as Chien-Pao after minor chip damage. Palafin is heavily hampered by Desolate Land; to take down their users, Zen Headbutt from Palafin-H easily OHKOes Iron Moth and 2HKOes Ceruledge, while Close Combat flings Cinderace into the sun. Pivoting teammates such as Kilowattrel, Meowscarada, and Corviknight not only form dangerous pivoting cores with Palafin, but also position it to both activate Zero to Hero and fire off its powerful Jet Punch. Due to its frequent need to switch and reliance on a recoil move to wallbreak, Palafin requires effective entry hazard removers like Corviknight and Donphan; WishPass Scream Tail is also a great teammate to heal off chip damage. Even with its strong coverage moves, Palafin struggles mightily against opposing Desolate Land, so reliable switch-ins like Well-Baked Body Slither Wing are strongly recommended. Palafin struggles against Dondozo, making teammates that can punish it like Meowscarada and Spikes Garchomp good additions.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Kingambit excels as a mid-game wallbreaker that can boost on passive foes and tear through the opponent's team with its Adaptability-boosted STAB attacks. Kowtow Cleave and Iron Head are Kingambit's main attacks, heavily damaging defensive pivots like Corviknight, Hisuian Goodra, Scream Tail, and Garganacl. Sucker Punch lets it predict and punish faster attackers like Quaquaval, Volcarona, and Slither Wing that try and come in to revenge kill. 140 Speed EVs let Kingambit outspeed uninvested Corviknight and Skeledirge. Black Glasses lets Kingambit OHKO Iron Moth with Sucker Punch. Immunity abilities like Well-Baked Body and Earth Eater are options to pick up additional setup chances. Fast endgame sweepers like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Hisuian Electrode benefit from Kingambit's early-game presence, capitalizing on chipped foes and scoring easy KOs. Defensive pivots like Intimidate Corviknight, RegenVest Meloetta, and Fluffy Landorus-T can thwart revenge killers targeting Kingambit and use U-turn to bring it in safely again. Finally, Primordial Sea Zapdos can help Kingambit by forcing Corviknight and Quaquaval, two of its most consistent checks, letting it chip them on their switch-in repeatedly.

Physically Defensive.description: Great Tusk's gargantuan physical bulk and access to valuable utility moves make it a valuable defensive presence in the metagame, especially since it is the best user of Rapid Spin and one of the few viable forms of entry hazard control. Body Press, when coupled with maximum Defense investment, deals consistent damage to Corviknight, while Ice Spinner can be used to hit Flying-type switch-ins like both Zapdos formes and Dragonite. Knock Off debilitates switch-ins like Corviknight and Zapdos by removing their Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots, respectively. Alternatively, Great Tusk can use Stealth Rock if none of its teammates are capable of setting it. Bulk Up can also be considered to increase Great Tusk's offensive presence, but is typically less preferred than other utility options. Scrappy notably prevents Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Pecharunt from spinblocking Great Tusk. Alternatively, Regenerator provides Great Tusk with reliable recovery it otherwise lacks, while Fluffy allows it to better check attackers such as Roaring Moon and allows a teammate like Swampert to use Regenerator instead. Heavy-Duty Boots ensures Great Tusk can more reliably remove entry hazards by avoiding chip damage from them, while Leftovers provides recovery for non-Regenerator sets, and Rocky Helmet can be used to punish attackers that make contact. Offensive Pokemon that appreciate entry hazards off the field such as Azelf and Chien-Pao pair well with Great Tusk's Rapid Spin support. Due to its poor special bulk, Great Tusk appreciates specially bulky Pokemon, such as Heatran, Empoleon, and if not using Regenerator, RegenVest Pokemon such as Manaphy and Swampert. Certain physical wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao and Galarian Zapdos are significant threats to Great Tusk, so it appreciates a secondary physical wall capable of checking these Pokemon such as Corviknight or Skarmory.

Offensive Bulk Up.description: Impressive offensive and defensive utility combined with the ability to remove entry hazards cements Great Tusk as a threatening sweeper that also takes on threats like Ceruledge, Iron Hands, and Roaring Moon. Ice Spinner lets Great Tusk hit Flying-types like Dragonite, Zapdos, and Mandibuzz, while Knock Off instead debilitates defensive switch-ins like Mandibuzz, Fluffy Corviknight, and opposing Great Tusk. Headlong Rush helps deal with Poison-types like Pecharunt and Iron Moth as well as being Great Tusk's best option against Fairy-types like Scream Tail. Scrappy + Rapid Spin grants Great Tusk hazard removal that's not blocked by Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Pecharunt. Scrappy also notably enables Great Tusk to turn Intimidate Corviknight into setup fodder. Hazard-weak Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, Ceruledge, and Ogerpon-H appreciate Great Tusk's role as a spinner; in return, they can help threaten physically defensive checks like Fluffy Corviknight and Deoxys-D, making it easier for it to set up. Due to its mediocre Special Defense, Great Tusk is forced out by common threats such as Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Walking Wake, making specially defensive teammates such as RegenVest Swampert, Meloetta, and Manaphy necessary. Despite its fantastic natural physical bulk, Great Tusk is troubled by certain wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao, Galarian Zapdos, and all Ogerpon formes, making physically defensive teammates such as Intimidate Skarmory, Fluffy Corviknight, and Unaware Deoxys-D greatly appreciated.

Pixilate.description: Scream Tail is a good offensive Pokemon that takes advantage of Boomburst's high Base Power when combined with Pixilate to act as an entry hazard setter or a late-game setup sweeper. With its fantastic defenses, good defensive typing, and great Speed tier, which lets it outspeed the Ogerpon formes, Latios, and Waking Wake, it can threaten most of the tier, notably entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Mandibuzz and common offensive threats such as Dragonite, Iron Hands, Galarian Zapdos, and Roaring Moon. Stealth Rock takes advantage of the switches that Scream Tail forces against Pokemon like Great Tusk, chipping down walls for itself and its teammates to break through them, while Calm Mind provides it with opportunities to sweep late-game once Pokemon like Iron Moth and Heatran have been removed. Wish can help Scream Tail and its teammates like Great Tusk and Iron Hands that lack reliable recovery options restore HP. Protect lets Scream Tail scout out Choice-locked foes like Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Roaring Moon and recover HP safely with Leftovers or Wish. Scream Tail has a hard time breaking through stout specially defensive Pokemon like Swampert, Meloetta, and Manaphy without Calm Mind, making it appreciate offensive partners like Hisuian Electrode, Roaring Moon, and Iron Boulder. Scream Tail is very susceptible to being revenge killed by faster Pokemon like Iron Boulder and Barraskewda, which makes it appreciate having teammates that can offer it a defensive backbone like Fluffy Corviknight and Skarmory. Scream Tail can also appreciate Knock Off users like Roaring Moon and Empoleon, which can remove items like Assault Vest and Heavy-Duty Boots from Manaphy and Zapdos respectively. Spikes setters like Skarmory and Deoxys-D have great synergy with Scream Tail, spreading entry hazards with it, which can help break it through RegenVest users like Swampert and Manaphy.

Unaware.description: Scream Tail uses its good bulk and great typing to be a superb Unaware wall, taking hits from boosted attackers such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, and Tail Glow Manaphy. It can also act as a Wish passer for teammates without reliable healing such as Roaring Moon, non-Regenerator Great Tusk, and Primarina. Calm Mind can be used in order to take on special threats like Zapdos and Deoxys-S, while Thunder Wave is an option to cripple switch-ins like Iron Moth, Gholdengo, and Ceruledge. Offensive Pokemon like Barraskewda, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao appreciate Scream Tail being able to take on Pokemon like Iron Hands, Great Tusk, and Dragonite while also providing them with healing. Scream Tail struggles with Ghost-types such as Gholdengo, Gengar, and Ceruledge, so having checks to them like Manaphy, Mandibuzz, and Roaring Moon can help.Teammates like Corviknight and Great Tusk can aid Scream Tail by removing the entry hazards that can wear it down. Finally, Scream Tail appreciates the presence of defensive checks to Chien-Pao, Ogerpon-W, and Iron Boulder such as Manaphy, Mandibuzz, and Corviknight, as it struggles to take them on repeatedly.

Choice Band.description: Slither Wing's massive Attack stat alongside its powerful STAB moves makes it a strong wallbreaker, pivot, and revenge killer, able to threaten common physical walls like Corviknight, Deoxys-D, and Mandibuzz. First Impression lets Slither Wing pick off faster offensive threats like Chien-Pao, Latios, and Roaring Moon. Flare Blitz threatens Fluffy users like Corviknight, Zapdos, and Great Tusk as well as non-Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, while Earthquake threatens Ceruledge, Pecharunt, and non-Earth Eater Gholdengo. Tinted Lens helps Slither Wing revenge kill offensive threats like Dragonite, Zapdos, and Volcarona and boosts the power of U-turn against foes like Great Tusk, while Sword of Ruin lets Slither Wing OHKO Deoxys-D after entry hazard chip damage with U-turn, OHKO Fluffy Corviknight with Flare Blitz, OHKO Gholdengo with Earthquake, and 2HKO Defensive Great Tusk with Close Combat. While more niche, Scrappy lets it OHKO Gholdengo with Close Combat while still 2HKOing Intimidate Corviknight. Fast cleaners like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Iron Boulder appreciate Slither Wing's ability to pressure their walls like Corviknight and Gholdengo, letting them sweep late-game once those walls have been chipped down or removed. Slither Wing's middling speed and only decent bulk leaves it vulnerable to offensive threats that do not fear First Impression like Ceruledge, Dragonite, and Azelf, making checks to them like Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Heatran, respectively, valuable teammates. Slither Wing is also prone to getting worn down by entry hazards, so hazard removers like Mandibuzz and the aforementioned Great Tusk and Corviknight are greatly appreciated.

Offensive Pivot.description: Sandy Shocks leverages a great typing, solid Speed tier, and access to entry hazards and Volt Switch to be a solid offensive pivot. Volt Switch allows Sandy Shocks to pivot out of uncomfortable matchups such as Meloetta, RegenVest Roaring Moon, and Blissey. Entry hazards allow Sandy Shocks to consistently pressure foes, with Stealth Rock being a notable option over Spikes to hit Chien-Pao and Ceruledge, and they synergize well with its STAB moves which naturally threaten common hazard removers such as Corviknight and Great Tusk. Choice Scarf helps Sandy Shocks to alleviate its unimpressive Speed, turning it into a potent revenge killer and cleaner, outpacing threats such as Modest Deoxys-S, Iron Boulder, and Cinderace, while Heavy-Duty Boots allows it to bypass entry hazards, turning it into a more durable pivot and not locking it into a single move. Sandy Shocks works excellently with powerful physical pivots such as Meowscarada, Barraskewda, and Roaring Moon, threatening common physical walls such as Corviknight and Great Tusk and giving these physical wallbreakers opportunities while forming a potent VoltTurn core. Sandy Shocks is frail and struggles to switch in against non-Electric-types; defensive pivots such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Swampert are all appreciated to help alleviate this.

RegenVest.description: Iron Treads is a niche RegenVest wall that offers valuable Rapid Spin utility, pivoting, and a unique typing that resists the tier's common Psychic- and Electric-type special attacks. Volt Switch provides pivoting while also chipping switch-ins like Corviknight and Manaphy, whereas Knock Off greatly reduces the longevity of defensive walls, notably Great Tusk and Swampert who would normally come in to absorb Volt Switch. Iron Treads is a pain to deal with for fast Electric-types, including Hisuian Electrode and non-Weather Ball Zapdos, and it can survive a Focus Blast from Thundurus or an Earth Power from Sandy Shocks. It also acts as a reliable answer to Azelf, Latios, and Gholdengo, threatening them with Knock Off while not being crippled by Trick. Iron Treads fits best on stall teams, providing much-needed hazard removal while relying on other specially defensive walls like Empoleon and Blissey to cover its weaknesses to common special attackers such as Walking Wake, Primarina, and Iron Moth. Iron Treads also appreciates physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Toxapex, as it naturally loses to some of the tier's most common physical wallbreakers such as Ceruledge, Chien-Pao, and Galarian Zapdos. Iron Treads can also be run as a role compression option on more offensive teams, as it can provide semi-reliable pivoting and Rapid Spin support for Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-H; in return, they threaten the Ground-types that Iron Treads struggles against such as the aforementioned Swampert and Great Tusk.

Earth Eater.description: Swords Dance, huge bulk, and a good defensive typing allow Iron Hands to become an incredibly threatening wallbreaker. Earth Eater allows it to set up on would-be checks like Swampert, Great Tusk, and Sandy Shocks. Substitute allows it to take advantage of foes like Empoleon, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao, which are forced out by it, allowing it valuable turns to set up. 172 Special Defense EVs allow its Substitute and withstand a Scald from RegenVest Manaphy, while 196 Speed EVs let it outspeed Manaphy. It is next to impossible to OHKO a full health Iron Hands behind dual screens, so support from Prankster Corviknight and Deoxys-S on hyper offense teams can help by allowing it extra turns to set up and letting it beat would-be offensive checks like Latios and Primarina. Iron Hands struggles against Unaware Pokemon, in particular Deoxys-D and Scream Tail, so teammates that can threaten them like Gengar and Ceruledge make for good partners. Barraskewda and Chien-Pao are teammates that enjoy the presence of Iron Hands, as it is excellent at trading itself to remove would-be checks to them like physically defensive Primarina and Manaphy, Intimidate Corviknight, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon. Strong special attackers like Deoxys-S, Azelf, and Walking Wake can be troublesome for Iron Hands, forcing it out; as a result, bulky special walls like Swampert, Manaphy, and Blissey are appreciated by it.

Surge Surfer.description: Surge Surfer Iron Hands is a great wallbreaker, leveraging the Speed boost procured by its ability to outspeed almost the entire unboosted metagame and set up with Swords Dance in order to break though opposing teams. It also has a great matchup against a lot of defensive staples such as Corviknight and Gholdengo. Ice Punch allows Iron Hands to hit Garchomp and foes that resist its STAB combination such as Latios, Dragonite, and Landorus-T for greater damage. Since Iron Hands is reliant on Electric Terrain to function, it must be paired with a Hadron Engine pivot such as Latios or Sandy Shocks, both of which can apply additional pressure on Great Tusk; in return, Iron Hands can beat Pokemon that Sandy Shocks is unable to hit such as Landorus-T. Iron Hands is not a conventional wallbreaker, and it can struggle to power through teams on its own; therefore, teammates such as Roaring Moon and Iron Boulder are appreciated, as they can apply pressure on Pokemon such as Deoxys-D and physically defensive Great Tusk, respectively, which Iron Hands struggles against. Pivots such as Roaring Moon and Galarian Zapdos are also great partners, as they can bait in Pokemon that Iron Hands can easily take advantage of to set up, such as Primarina and Corviknight.

RegenVest.description: Iron Hands's great natural bulk and typing let it serve as a potent mixed wall and pivot, checking and scouting common threats like Gholdengo, Iron Moth, Chien-Pao, and Dragonite. Drain Punch provides a drawback-free STAB move with recovery, while Close Combat grants more immediate power, being able to 2HKO Swampert. Earthquake allows Iron Hands to threaten offensive wallbreakers like Gengar, Iron Moth, and Gholdengo, while Ice Punch can help to hit Ground-types like Great Tusk that can block Volt Switch and Flying-types like Zapdos and Dragonite. Iron Hands struggles with strong Psychic- and Fairy-type wallbreakers like Azelf and Primarina, so it appreciates partners like Empoleon and Mandibuzz that can help with these matchups. Iron Hands dislikes common defensive Ground-types like Great Tusk and Swampert that can block its attempt to pivot with Volt Switch, and it can struggle against particularly strong physical wallbreakers like Choice Band Galarian Zapdos, so it partners well with walls that can handle them like Corviknight and Deoxys-D. Frail offensive wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Azelf appreciate Iron Hands's ability to safely pivot them onto the field and wall revenge killers like Choice Scarf Walking Wake and Roaring Moon.

Sheer Force.description: With high-Base Power moves and decent Special Attack and Speed, Iron Jugulis is a solid wallbreaker that can outspeed and threaten common specially defensive foes, like Garchomp and Garganacl. Iron Jugulis offers a notable niche, as Hurricane + Dark Pulse + Focus Blast can hit every viable Pokemon for neutral damage. Taunt disrupts attempts to heal, set up, or set entry hazards, allowing Iron Jugulis to better handle Pokemon such as Blissey and Clodsire. Iron Jugulis struggles against special walls like Florges and Scream Tail, so physically offensive teammates like Cinderace and Ceruledge are necessary to break through them. Due to its frailty, it enjoys teammates like Slither Wing and Corviknight that can pivot it in, the latter of which can also remove hazards with Defog. Iron Jugulis also appreciates entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu, which can enable it to secure KOs that it would typically miss, such as Garganacl.

Desolate Land.description: Iron Moth functions as an offensive pivot that can also opt to spread status. U-turn allows Iron Moth to gain momentum on switch-ins such as Manaphy, Swampert, and Meloetta, as well as Fire-immune foes such as Well-Baked Body Gholdengo and Corviknight. Toxic and Toxic Spikes allow Iron Moth to chip down defensive Pokemon. Energy Ball is decent coverage against would-be switch-ins like Manaphy, Swampert, and Primordial Sea Barraskewda. Dazzling Gleam hits Dragon-types like Roaring Moon, Walking Wake, and Dragonite. Discharge hits Manaphy and Well-Baked Body Corviknight and can notably paralyze Well-Baked Body Gholdengo. Desolate Land effectively grants Iron Moth a Water immunity, enabling it to switch into Ogerpon-W, Barraskewda, and Primarina for its team. Pokemon with setup moves like Ogerpon-W appreciate Iron Moth's ability to bait in RegenVest users like Manaphy and Meloetta and pivot on them. Iron Moth does pitiful damage to RegenVest users like Manaphy, Meloetta, and Hisuian Goodra, so it benefits from special wallbreakers like Deoxys-S, Walking Wake, and Latios that can lure in and help wear down shared checks; they also appreciate Iron Moth chipping said checks, especially with Toxic or Toxic Spikes.

Physically Defensive.description: Gholdengo's naturally good offensive presence, fantastic typing, and access to reliable recovery combine to make it a staple defensive piece. Hex can be run over Shadow Ball in conjunction with Thunder Wave to increase its maximum Base Power while spreading paralysis to support Gholdengo's teammates. Well-Baked Body allows Gholdengo to wall Pokemon reliant on Fire-type moves to beat it, such as Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Ogerpon-H lacking Knock Off. Similarly, Earth Eater handles opposing Ground-types such as non-Scrappy Great Tusk. Bulletproof is used to negate Shadow Ball from Gengar, Hisuian Zoroark, and opposing Gholdengo. Gholdengo's natural typing allows it to use nearly any immunity ability effectively, so options like Water Absorb and Volt Absorb can also be used depending on the needs of its team, although these are generally less effective. 28 Speed EVs are used to outspeed minimally invested Great Tusk, with the remaining EVs being used to maximize Gholdengo's physical bulk to better check physical attackers. Gholdengo is particularly vulnerable to Dark-types like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao, and many Pokemon like Iron Boulder and Ogerpon-C run Dark-type coverage specifically to hit all variants of it. Thus, Pokemon that can take hits from Dark-type attackers such as Corviknight and Great Tusk make good partners. Gholdengo cannot check most special attackers, so it appreciates having special walls such as Swampert and Manaphy as teammates. Finally, Gholdengo can be taken advantage of and used for momentum by RegenVest Pokemon such as Swampert and Meloetta, so it appreciates strong wallbreakers such as Roaring Moon and Galarian Zapdos to bust through these walls.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Chien-Pao is a strong wallbreaker, being able to blast through many teams on its own. Its high Attack and Speed combined with its good STAB moves and Choice Band to bolster its damage even further make it extremely difficult to handle. Lash Out can be used over Crunch to hit Intimidate Corviknight harder. Ice Shard helps to pick up KOs on weakened, faster foes like Galarian Zapdos and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon; it can also OHKO frail targets like Hisuian Electrode from full HP. Sacred Sword hits Dark-, Steel-, and Rock-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Garganacl. Chien-Pao can have a hard time breaking through defensive Pokemon like Intimidate Corviknight and Quaquaval, making partners like Ceruledge and Dragonite appreciated. Choice Scarf users like Walking Wake can be tough foes for Chien-Pao, forcing it out; this makes slow pivots like Meloetta and RegenVest Manaphy good teammates, as they can deal with these Choice Scarf users and also help bring it in safely after taking a hit. Chien-Pao's weakness to Stealth Rock can become a problem quickly if not accounted for, so entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Mandibuzz are good partners.

Swords Dance.description: Access to Swords Dance and a high Attack and Speed stat make Chien-Pao a powerful wallbreaker and sweeper. It also has a STAB combination that is resisted by few Pokemon; hits physical walls like Mandibuzz, Deoxys-D, and Great Tusk super effectively; and can OHKO many offensive threats like Walking Wake after a Swords Dance. Ice Shard picks off faster foes like Hisuian Electrode and, after some chip damage, Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Sandy Shocks. Adaptability lets Chien-Pao OHKO Iron Moth and makes breaking through walls like Intimidate Corviknight easier, while Magic Guard offers more longevity. Special attackers like Latios and Azelf appreciate Chien-Pao being able to threaten their switch-ins like Gholdengo and Swampert, letting them rip massive holes in or sweep teams; they can also safely pivot it in, allowing more opportunities for it to deal significant damage. Chien-Pao appreciates other physical wallbreakers like Choice Band Roaring Moon and Galarian Zapdos helping break through walls like Intimidate Corviknight that it struggles to deal with. Chien-Pao is also prone to getting revenge killed by Choice Scarf users such as Walking Wake and Azelf, so teammates that can switch into them and safely pivot it in like Swampert and Empoleon are appreciated.

Specially Defensive.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Earth Eater Kingambit, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Talonflame and Quaquaval. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail and Lucario can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Corviknight is a good teammate that also provides Defog.

RegenVest Wall.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Hydreigon and Iron Moth. Throat Chop provides STAB damage and lets it beat Boomburst users, Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon and Blissey. Some special attackers like Scream Tail can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options. Ting-Lu can switch into weaker physical attackers like Roaring Moon, but it should be used as help for the main physical wall on the team. Ting-Lu is vulnerable to opposing setup sweepers, so teammates like Unaware Corviknight are greatly appreciated. Corviknight can also reduce Ting-Lu's weakness to entry hazards.

Choice Item Attacker.description: Chi-Yu's strong base stats and excellent STAB coverage make it a flexible offensive threat. Choice Specs provides maximum wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to OHKO physically defensive Ting-Lu with Desolate Land + Overheat, whereas Choice Scarf gives it the Speed to clean late-game and chase out faster threats like Cinderace and Chien-Pao. Desolate Land provides the most damage amplification and comes with an immunity to Water, whereas No Guard enables Chi-Yu to liberally spread burns with Inferno. Psychic is useful coverage to hit Clodsire and Iron Moth super effectively; alternatively, Will-O-Wisp allows Desolate Land sets to reliably spread burn, however Chi-Yu's poor bulk means it can be dangerous to use. Chi-Yu's best fit is on balance and offense teams that appreciate its high damage output, as well as its good matchups against common special walls like RegenVest Iron Treads. Bulky pivots, like the aforementioned Corviknight and Iron Treads, make particularly good Chi-Yu partners because both can clear entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock.

Nasty Plot.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack and decent Speed, Chi-Yu is a potent wallbreaker that makes use of Nasty Plot and its unresisted STAB combination to tear through common walls like Sand Stream Garganacl and non-Unaware Florges. Chi-Yu generally prefers to run Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid entry hazard damage, but Life Orb can be run on Sheer Force sets for extra power. Chi-Yu also has several Fire-type STAB moves to choose from: Fire Blast is the most powerful, Flamethrower is the most consistent option, and Inferno is used on No Guard sets to punish switch-ins like Garganacl and Ting-Lu with a burn. Chi-Yu does struggle against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey, so physically offensive Pokemon like Meowscarada and Kingambit make good teammates. Chi-Yu is also physically frail, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Avalugg that can switch into strong physical attacks and Wish passers like Florges and Scream Tail that can help it stay healthy.

Choice Item.description: No matter which of Choice Band or Choice Scarf you decide to use, rest assured: Roaring Moon will be able to blast holes in the enemy team. A high Attack combined with the power of Sword of Ruin as well as a good Speed tier allows it to function as a potent wallbreaker or revenge killer, depending on your choice of item. Earthquake and Stone Edge allow Roaring Moon to hit Steel-types such as Heatran and Fairy-types such as Enamorus-T, which resists both of its STAB moves, respectively. Lash Out is a good option to punish Intimidate Corviknight. Choice Scarf allows Roaring Moon to act as excellent speed control, outspeeding and revenge killing threats like Azelf and Deoxys-S, while Choice Band lets it OHKO Unaware Deoxys-D and Galarian Zapdos. Roaring Moon struggles against Fluffy Corviknight and defensive Great Tusk, so partners such as Azelf and Ogerpon-H are appreciated; in return, it can threaten their checks like Gholdengo and Walking Wake.

Dragon Dance.description: Due to its high Attack and Speed further augmented by Dragon Dance, Roaring Moon functions incredibly as a threatening setup sweeper. Iron Head provides coverage for Fairy-types like Scream Tail, while Stone Edge nails Mandibuzz and can bypass Fluffy walls like Corviknight. Outrage is used to deal massive damage to physically bulky Pokemon such as Iron Hands at the cost of confusion; alternatively, Acrobatics can be used to handle Great Tusk and most Ogerpon formes after Weakness Policy's activation. Weakness Policy can easily be activated by a weak U-turn from Corviknight, Manaphy, or Azelf, while Life Orb provides consistent damage. Applicable partners include Prankster Corviknight for its dual screens support and ability to pivot Roaring Moon in safely, and Gholdengo, since it has incredible type synergy with Roaring Moon, being able to resist Fairy, Dragon, Bug, Ice, and having an immunity to Fighting. Roaring Moon struggles against defensive Great Tusk, especially Fluffy variants, and Fluffy Corviknight. With partners such as Azelf and Manaphy for Great Tusk and Iron Moth and Ogerpon-H for Corviknight, Roaring Moon's biggest checks and counters become quite threatened. Additionally, wallbreakers such as Choice Band Iron Boulder and Chien-Pao can both physically wear down defensive walls to clear the way for Roaring Moon to get a clean sweep.

RegenVest.description: Roaring Moon's excellent set of resistances, great Speed and Attack, and solid bulk make it a serviceable bulky pivot without the passivity of other RegenVest Pokemon like Manaphy and Swampert; in particular, its great typing allows it to scout and offensively check and prominent special attackers like Gholdengo, Iron Moth, and Hisuian Electrode. U-turn allows it to maintain high momentum, pivoting out of difficult matchups like against Great Tusk and Fluffy Corviknight and healing off any chip damage with Regenerator. Earthquake allows it to hit Steel-types like Kingambit and Heatran, which would otherwise trouble it. Roaring Moon tends to play aggressively, with its average bulk contributing to it being seen mainly on offensive teams; therefore, hard-hitting offensive teammates like Ogerpon-C, Chien-Pao, and Azelf enjoy its presence. Roaring Moon cannot safely switch in on strong Dragon-types like Latios and Walking Wake, so a secondary special wall like Empoleon or Scream Tail makes for an excellent partner. Entry hazards severely compromise Roaring Moon's longevity, and its lack of physical bulk makes it reliant on strong physical walls to take hits instead; as a result, physically defensive hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight are nearly essential partners.

Choice Item.description: Walking Wake is a strong wallbreaker thanks to its high Special Attack and powerful STAB moves with excellent coverage. Choice Specs can be run to provide Walking Wake with more wallbreaking power, notably giving it a chance to 2HKO RegenVest Swampert, while Choice Scarf helps to make up for its relatively poor Speed and lets it outspeed and OHKO the likes of Chien-Pao and Deoxys-S. Weather Ball is run on Primordial Sea sets for consistency and to chunk Desolate Land Heatran, while Hydro Pump is preferred on Dragon's Maw variants. Draco Meteor hits Desolate Land Iron Moth and Water-resistant switch-ins like RegenVest Manaphy and Hisuian Goodra, outdamaging Regenerator on the latter two and OHKOing the former with Dragon's Maw sets. Knock Off can be run to let Walking Wake better enable its own wallbreaking by crippling RegenVest Pokemon, while Scald and Dragon Pulse can be used if its team already has Knock Off support as more consistent damaging options with no drawbacks and, in the case of Scald, the chance to burn foes. Flip Turn allows Walking Wake to maintain momentum and pivot in teammates safely. Due to its middling Speed when running Choice Specs, Walking Wake is susceptible to being revenge killed by Chien-Pao and Gengar, so it appreciates teammates like Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Azelf that can take care of faster threats. While Walking Wake can play around RegenVest Pokemon with Knock Off, it still benefits from physically offensive teammates like Galarian Zapdos and Iron Boulder that can more easily handle them. Due to its lack of recovery, Walking Wake appreciates entry hazard removal support from the likes of Great Tusk and Corviknight to allow it to come in safely.

Swords Dance.description: Fantastic STAB coverage, a solid Speed tier, and good coverage options all make Ogerpon-W a force to be reckoned with, being able to shatter most of the tier's physical walls such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Mandibuzz after a Swords Dance. Power Whip packs more of a punch, letting it OHKO RegenVest Manaphy without a Swords Dance boost, while Horn Leech grants it more longevity. Knock Off lets it threaten Desolate Land users such as Iron Moth, Ceruledge, and Heatran, while Play Rough picks off Dragon-types such as Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Latios. Trailblaze enables Ogerpon-W to act as more of a sweeper, letting it outspeed threats such as Iron Boulder, Chien-Pao, and Deoxys-S, while Spikes can be used to help chip down Hisuian Goodra and other walls for its teammates. Ogerpon-W pairs well with fast cleaners such as Iron Boulder and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, as they appreciate its ability to pressure Fluffy users such as Corviknight and Great Tusk thanks to Ivy Cudgel not making contact. In spite of its solid speed, Ogerpon-W is still threatened by faster targets such as Chien-Pao, Choice Scarf Azelf, and Roaring Moon, making defensive pivots such as Corviknight and Swampert crucial in order to bring it in safely.

Thanks to its great Attack stat, its strong STAB moves, and Swords Dance, Ogerpon-H is a powerful wallbreaker that's able to threaten common physical walls like Deoxys-D and non-Well-Baked Body Corviknight. Power Whip OHKOes defensive Great Tusk at +2 and has a good chance to OHKO offensive Great Tusk, while Horn Leech trades power for healing and a guaranteed chance to hit. Play Rough threatens Dragon-types like Dragonite and Roaring Moon looking to switch in, while Knock Off has a high chance of OHKOing Well-Baked Body Gholdengo at +2 and hinders switch-ins like Primordial Sea Zapdos and Well-Baked Body Mandibuzz and Corviknight. Fast cleaners like Choice Scarf Azelf and Chien-Pao appreciate Ogerpon-H's ability to threaten their switch-ins like RegenVest Swampert and Intimidate Corviknight, respectively, paving the way for them to clean late-game. Ogerpon-H's middling bulk and only decent Speed stat leave it threatened by many faster offensive foes like Roaring Moon and Iron Boulder, so teammates that can deal with them offensively like the aforementioned Choice Scarf Azelf and Chien-Pao or defensively like Great Tusk and Corviknight, which can also remove the entry hazards that Ogerpon-H is prone to getting worn down by, are appreciated. Entry hazard support from the likes of Great Tusk and Heatran is also appreciated, as it helps Ogerpon-H KO foes like Gholdengo and Deoxys-D.

When boosted by the power of Rocky Payload and its Cornerstone Mask, Ogerpon-C is a devastating wallbreaker that's capable of threatening nearly the entire metagame due to the lack of capable Rock-resistant Pokemon. Power Whip is Ogerpon-C's strongest Grass-type attack, OHKOing specially defensive Manaphy and having a good chance to OHKO offensive Great Tusk, while Horn Leech can provide recovery if desired. For the last moveslot, Knock Off has a good chance of OHKOing Gholdengo at +2, Low Kick deals with Hisuian Goodra and Kingambit, and Trailblaze increases Ogerpon-C's effectiveness against faster teams. Other physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon appreciate Ogerpon-C's presence, as together they can overwhelm physical walls such as Corviknight, Skarmory, and Great Tusk. Ogerpon-C's poor defensive typing and average Speed means it appreciates slow, bulky pivots such as Corviknight, RegenVest Swampert, and RegenVest Manaphy to provide it with safe entry onto the field. Its Speed also leaves it prone to getting picked off by faster offensive Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, so speedy teammates such as Barraskewda, Choice Scarf Azelf, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon are appreciated.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Iron Boulder is one of the best single-button clickers imaginable; honestly, the other moves are mostly decorative. Sharpness- and Choice Band-boosted Mighty Cleave has excellent power and coverage, notably 2HKOing Unaware Deoxys-D and OHKOing most slower offensive Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos and Roaring Moon. Psycho Cut covers important targets like Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Swampert, while Throat Chop reliably beats Gholdengo, and Sacred Sword beats Iron Treads and Hisuian Goodra. Iron Boulder has an awful defensive typing and greatly appreciates being brought in by slow pivots like Manaphy and Corviknight; thanks to its great Speed tier, it can usually force out the wallbreakers that come in on them in return. Iron Boulder also pairs well with other physically offensive threats like Barraskewda and Garchomp that can wear down opposing walls like Intimidate Corviknight with it. Fluffy walls such as Corviknight and Deoxys-D are extremely difficult for Iron Boulder to break past, so a strong Fire-type like Iron Moth or Ceruledge makes an excellent teammate.

Swords Dance.description: With an amazing Speed stat and great STAB moves, Iron Boulder stands out as one of the tier's strongest wallbreakers. Swords Dance lets it tear through some of the tier's most common physical walls including Great Tusk, Deoxys-D, and non-Fluffy Corviknight. Iron Boulder has plenty of options as a last move: Sacred Sword helps deal with Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra, Kingambit, and Iron Treads; Throat Chop notably hits Gholdengo; and Earthquake acts as a midground option, hitting the aformentioned Sacred Sword targets and non-Earth Eater Gholdengo at the cost of not getting boosted by Sharpness. Iron Boulder appreciates offensive pivots like Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, as they're able to clean up after it has weakened the physical walls. Iron Boulder also appreciates defensive pivots like Corviknight and Swampert, as they can bring it in safely. Despite its amazing Speed stat, it's still prone to getting revenge killed by faster targets like Chien-Pao, Hisuian Electrode, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon, making defensive walls like Corviknight, Meloetta, and Great Tusk necessary. Iron Boulder lacks damage without a boost from Swords Dance, so entry hazard setters like Deoxys-D, Sandy Shocks, and Skarmory are greatly appreciated, as they help chip foes into its KO range.

Double Dance.description: The combination of Calm Mind and Agility, which lets Iron Crown outspeed almost the entire metagame after just one use, gives it the potential to be a deadly setup sweeper. Stored Power gives Iron Crown scaling damage, letting it 2HKO offensive threats like Iron Moth and Zamazenta after one Agility and OHKO them after one Calm Mind with some chip damage. Additionally, it lets Iron Crown 2HKO specially defensive Garchomp and RegenVest Iron Hands at +4, which can be easily achieved by letting its Weakness Policy activate. Furthermore, with one Agility boost and after Weakness Policy has activated or Calm Mind has been used twice, it lets Iron Crown OHKO even Psychic-resistant Pokemon like Corviknight and Gholdengo and 2HKO most RegenVest users, like Manaphy and Swampert. Iron Crown is heavily reliant on setup moves to perform its role, so it is easily shut down by Taunt, can be stopped by dedicated special walls like Blissey and Chansey, and needs teammates like Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-H that can handle them. A dual screens setter like Corviknight or Deoxys-S is appreciated to help Iron Crown with both activating its Weakness Policy and setting up safely. Bulky Dark-types like Mandibuzz and Kingambit give Iron Crown a lot of trouble, so teammates like Galvanize Kommo-o and Iron Hands are needed to remove them.
